name: Forward Head Posture
description: The head sits 1+ inches forward of the shoulder line, placing excessive load on the cervical spine.
how_it_forms: Prolonged screen/phone use with head tilted forward
Desk work without ergonomic setup
Weak deep neck flexor muscles from disuse
Carrying heavy backpacks
Sleeping with too many pillows or on your stomach
why_fix: Every inch your head sits forward adds approximately 10 lbs of effective weight on your cervical spine. At 3 inches forward, your neck muscles are supporting 42 lbs instead of 12. This accelerates disc wear, compresses nerves exiting the cervical spine, and forces compensatory curves throughout the rest of the spine.
biomechanics_explanation: The cervical extensors (suboccipitals, upper traps, splenius) become chronically shortened to hold the head up against gravity. The deep neck flexors (longus colli, longus capitis) weaken from disuse. The upper cervical spine hyperextends while the lower cervical spine flexes, creating a shear force at C4-C5 and C5-C6.
chain_reaction: Forward head → rounds the upper back to compensate → shoulders roll forward → pecs shorten → mid-back weakens → thoracic kyphosis develops → ribcage compresses → breathing becomes shallow → anterior pelvic tilt may develop to rebalance center of gravity

severity_indicators.mild: Head slightly forward, occasional neck stiffness after prolonged sitting
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible forward shift, regular headaches, neck pain after desk work
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced forward shift, chronic pain, numbness/tingling in arms, TMJ issues

name: Rounded Shoulders
description: The shoulders roll forward and internally rotate, causing the chest to collapse inward and the upper back to round.
how_it_forms: Excessive time hunched over a desk or phone
Overtraining chest muscles (bench press) while neglecting back
Carrying bags on one shoulder repeatedly
Poor awareness of shoulder position during daily activities
Emotional posture — chronic stress or low confidence
why_fix: Rounded shoulders compress the subacromial space — the gap where your rotator cuff tendons pass through. Every time you raise your arm overhead, those tendons get pinched. Over years, this leads to fraying, inflammation, and eventually tears. Your lungs also can't fully expand when your ribcage is collapsed forward, reducing oxygen intake by up to 30%.
biomechanics_explanation: The pectoralis major and minor shorten, pulling the humeral head forward. The serratus anterior and lower trapezius weaken, losing their ability to retract and stabilize the scapula. The rotator cuff muscles (especially infraspinatus and teres minor) become lengthened and weak, reducing their ability to externally rotate the humerus.
chain_reaction: Rounded shoulders → scapulae protract and tilt → thoracic spine flexes to accommodate → ribcage compresses → diaphragm restricted → compensatory breathing with neck muscles → neck tension increases → forward head posture worsens

severity_indicators.mild: Shoulders slightly forward, correctable with conscious effort
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible rounding, difficulty holding shoulders back, discomfort when reaching overhead
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced rounding, chronic shoulder/upper back pain, shoulder impingement symptoms

name: Thoracic Kyphosis
description: Excessive rounding of the upper back (thoracic spine), creating a hunched or stooped appearance that goes beyond the normal thoracic curve.
how_it_forms: Years of slouched sitting posture
Osteoporosis causing vertebral compression fractures
Scheuermann's disease (developmental condition)
Weak thoracic extensors from sedentary lifestyle
Prolonged forward-leaning work positions
why_fix: The thoracic spine is designed to have a gentle curve of 20-45 degrees. When this exceeds 50 degrees, the vertebral bodies begin bearing load unevenly — more on the front than the back. This accelerates disc degeneration, increases fracture risk, and forces every other spinal region to compensate. Your lungs lose up to 30% expansion capacity, and your digestive organs get compressed.
biomechanics_explanation: The thoracic erector spinae and deep multifidus muscles become lengthened and weak. The anterior longitudinal ligament shortens. The pectorals and abdominal fascia tighten, pulling the ribcage down and forward. The thoracic vertebrae begin to wedge anteriorly over time, making the curve structural rather than just postural.
chain_reaction: Thoracic kyphosis → head moves forward to keep eyes level → shoulders round to follow the curve → ribcage compresses → diaphragm restricted → lumbar spine hyperextends to compensate → anterior pelvic tilt develops → hip flexors tighten

severity_indicators.mild: Slight upper back rounding, easily correctable with effort
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeable hunch, difficulty fully straightening, mid-back ache
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced hump, structural changes visible, chronic pain, breathing difficulty

name: Elevated Shoulders
description: One or both shoulders sit higher than normal, often hiked up toward the ears due to chronic tension in the upper trapezius and levator scapulae.
how_it_forms: Chronic stress causing unconscious shoulder hiking
Desk work with arms too high or keyboard too elevated
Carrying bags on one shoulder habitually
Breathing dysfunction — using neck muscles instead of diaphragm
Emotional guarding patterns from anxiety
why_fix: Chronically elevated shoulders compress the thoracic outlet — the space between your collarbone and first rib where major nerves and blood vessels pass to your arms. This compression can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hands. The constant muscle contraction also wastes energy and creates painful trigger points that refer pain to the head, face, and arms.
biomechanics_explanation: The upper trapezius and levator scapulae become chronically shortened and overactive, elevating the scapula. The lower trapezius, which should depress and stabilize the scapula, becomes inhibited. The diaphragm may be underactive, causing accessory breathing muscles (scalenes, SCM) to take over, which further elevates the shoulder girdle.
chain_reaction: Elevated shoulders → upper traps overwork → lower traps shut down → scapulae become unstable → shoulder mechanics alter → impingement risk increases → neck muscles overwork to stabilize → cervicogenic headaches develop

severity_indicators.mild: Slight shoulder elevation, noticeable when pointed out, relaxes easily
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible shoulder hiking, frequent tension, difficulty relaxing shoulders down
severity_indicators.severe: Chronic elevation, constant pain, trigger points, numbness in arms

name: Winged Scapula
description: The shoulder blade protrudes outward from the rib cage instead of lying flat, visible as a 'wing' shape on the back, especially during pushing movements.
how_it_forms: Weakness of the serratus anterior muscle
Long thoracic nerve damage or impingement
Overuse injuries from repetitive overhead activities
Poor push-up and pressing form over long periods
General deconditioning and sedentary lifestyle
why_fix: The scapula is the foundation for all arm movements. When it wings, the glenoid fossa (shoulder socket) doesn't position correctly, meaning every reach, push, pull, and lift happens on an unstable platform. This is like trying to shoot a cannon from a canoe — the force can't transfer properly, and surrounding structures take the abuse instead.
biomechanics_explanation: The serratus anterior is the primary scapular stabilizer that holds the medial border of the scapula flush against the rib cage. When it weakens, the scapula loses its anchor. The pectoralis minor then has an unopposed pull, tilting the scapula anteriorly. The lower trapezius also fails to upwardly rotate the scapula during arm elevation, leading to subacromial impingement.
chain_reaction: Winged scapula → scapula can't upwardly rotate → shoulder impingement during overhead movement → rotator cuff compensates → rotator cuff fatigue/injury → pain limits movement → further weakening → chronic instability

severity_indicators.mild: Slight scapular prominence, only visible during wall push-ups or loaded movements
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible winging at rest, difficulty with push-ups, clicking sensations
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced winging, significant weakness, pain with overhead movements, possible nerve involvement

name: Head Tilt
description: The head chronically tilts to one side, creating uneven loading on the cervical spine and asymmetric muscle tension patterns.
how_it_forms: Habitual phone cradling between ear and shoulder
Unilateral vision or hearing dominance compensation
Torticollis (congenital or acquired)
Scoliosis creating compensatory head positioning
Always sleeping on one side with poor pillow support
why_fix: A tilted head creates asymmetric loading on the cervical vertebrae. The facet joints on the shortened side get compressed while the opposite side gets stretched. Over years, this uneven wear degenerates the joints unevenly, can compress nerve roots on one side, and forces the entire spine to develop compensatory curves to keep the eyes level.
biomechanics_explanation: The scalenes, upper trapezius, and SCM on the shortened side become chronically contracted. The opposite side becomes lengthened and weak. The suboccipital muscles adapt asymmetrically, altering proprioceptive input from the upper cervical spine, which can affect balance and spatial orientation. The jaw may shift to compensate, loading the TMJ unevenly.
chain_reaction: Head tilt → cervical spine side-bends → shoulder elevates on short side → thoracic spine compensates with opposite curve → lumbar spine adds another compensatory curve → pelvis tilts laterally → full-body asymmetric pattern

severity_indicators.mild: Slight head tilt, only noticeable in photos, easily self-corrected
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible tilt, unilateral neck tension, occasional headaches on one side
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced tilt, chronic one-sided pain, TMJ symptoms, difficulty centering head

name: Anterior Pelvic Tilt
description: The pelvis tilts forward, causing the lower back to arch excessively and the belly to protrude, even in lean individuals.
how_it_forms: Prolonged sitting tightening the hip flexors
Weak gluteal muscles from disuse (sitting all day)
Weak abdominal muscles failing to stabilize the pelvis
High heels tilting the pelvis forward
Overtraining hip flexors without stretching (cycling, running)
why_fix: An anterior pelvic tilt of just 10 degrees beyond neutral increases compressive load on the lumbar facet joints by up to 40%. The lumbar discs also bear load unevenly — more on the posterior side — which accelerates disc bulging and herniation. Your glutes, the strongest muscles in the body, essentially turn off, forcing smaller muscles to do heavy lifting.
biomechanics_explanation: The iliopsoas and rectus femoris shorten, pulling the front of the pelvis down. The erector spinae in the lumbar region shorten to maintain the excessive lordotic curve. The gluteus maximus and abdominals lengthen and become inhibited — this is called 'lower cross syndrome.' The hamstrings are pulled taut across the tilted pelvis, making them feel tight even though they're actually lengthened.
chain_reaction: Anterior pelvic tilt → lumbar hyperextension → facet joint compression → glutes inhibited → hamstrings and lower back compensate → hamstring strains → knee stress increases → knee valgus may develop under load

severity_indicators.mild: Slight forward tilt, lower back tightness after standing long periods
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible arch in lower back, noticeable belly protrusion, regular lower back pain
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced tilt, chronic lower back pain, difficulty activating glutes, hip flexor pain

name: Posterior Pelvic Tilt
description: The pelvis tucks under, flattening the natural lumbar curve. The tailbone tucks forward and the lower back loses its lordotic arch.
how_it_forms: Prolonged slouched sitting with weight on the tailbone
Overactive hamstrings pulling the pelvis under
Weak hip flexors from excessive stretching or disuse
Chronic abdominal bracing or 'sucking in' habits
Tight gluteus maximus from excessive targeted training
why_fix: The lumbar lordosis exists for a reason — it's a shock absorber. When you flatten it, axial loads (gravity, walking, running) transfer directly through the disc bodies instead of being distributed across the curve. This dramatically increases intradiscal pressure, especially at L4-L5 and L5-S1, which are already the most vulnerable levels.
biomechanics_explanation: The hamstrings and gluteus maximus become shortened, pulling the ischial tuberosities (sit bones) under the pelvis. The abdominals may be overactive, pulling the front of the pelvis up. The hip flexors (iliopsoas) become lengthened and weak. The lumbar erector spinae lose their activation pattern, and the lumbar multifidus atrophies, removing critical spinal stability.
chain_reaction: Posterior pelvic tilt → lumbar curve flattens → thoracic spine rounds more to compensate → head moves forward → reduced shock absorption in spine → increased disc pressure → disc degeneration at L4-L5, L5-S1

severity_indicators.mild: Slightly flat lower back, mild discomfort when trying to arch
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeably flat back, difficulty maintaining lumbar curve when sitting, regular stiffness
severity_indicators.severe: Completely flat lumbar spine, chronic lower back pain, disc-related symptoms

name: Lateral Pelvic Tilt
description: One hip sits higher than the other when standing, creating an asymmetric base that forces the entire spine to compensate with side-bending curves.
how_it_forms: Habitual standing with weight on one leg
Leg length discrepancy (true or functional)
Unilateral hip muscle weakness (gluteus medius)
Scoliosis creating pelvic asymmetry
Hip joint dysfunction or past injury on one side

short_term: IT band tightness on one side

why_fix: The pelvis is the foundation of the spine. When it tilts laterally, the lumbar spine must create an S-curve to keep your head over your center of gravity. This puts asymmetric loads on every disc, facet joint, and muscle from pelvis to skull. The hip on the high side gets compressed, while the low side gets stretched — both accelerating wear patterns that can lead to premature arthritis.
biomechanics_explanation: On the elevated side, the quadratus lumborum and hip adductors become shortened. The gluteus medius on the opposite (dropped) side is weak, failing to stabilize the pelvis during single-leg stance. The tensor fasciae latae and IT band on the high side become tight. The lumbar spine develops a compensatory curve, and the thoracic spine adds another curve above it.
chain_reaction: Lateral pelvic tilt → lumbar spine side-bends to compensate → thoracic spine bends opposite way → cervical spine tilts to level the eyes → uneven loading on hip joints → knee tracks inward on low side → foot overpronates on low side → full-body asymmetric pattern

severity_indicators.mild: Slight pelvic unevenness, visible only with careful observation
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeable hip height difference, one-sided pain patterns, gait visible unevenness
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced tilt, chronic asymmetric pain, compensatory scoliosis, difficulty with balance

name: Lumbar Hyperlordosis
description: An exaggerated inward curve of the lower back, going beyond the normal 40-60 degrees of lumbar lordosis, creating excessive compression on the posterior spinal structures.
how_it_forms: Anterior pelvic tilt pulling the lumbar spine into extension
Weak core muscles failing to control spinal position
Pregnancy or significant abdominal weight
Dancers and gymnasts overtraining extension
Wearing high heels regularly shifting center of gravity
why_fix: Hyperlordosis crushes the facet joints together at the back of each vertebra. These joints aren't designed to bear heavy loads — they're guidance rails. When forced to become load-bearing, they develop arthritis rapidly. The spinal canal also narrows in extension, potentially compressing the spinal cord and nerve roots. This is one of the most common causes of chronic lower back pain in adults under 50.
biomechanics_explanation: The lumbar erector spinae become chronically shortened, holding the spine in extension. The iliopsoas maintains a forward pull on the lumbar vertebrae (especially L1-L3). The abdominals are lengthened and cannot generate sufficient intra-abdominal pressure to stabilize the spine. The posterior annulus of the lumbar discs gets compressed while the anterior annulus is stretched.
chain_reaction: Lumbar hyperlordosis → facet joints overload → nerve roots compressed → compensatory thoracic kyphosis develops above → glutes inhibited below → hamstrings and lower back compensate for hip extension → hamstring strains and lower back spasms

severity_indicators.mild: Slightly exaggerated lumbar curve, occasional lower back stiffness
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeable excessive arch, regular lower back pain, difficulty flattening back against wall
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced lordosis, chronic pain, radiating symptoms, difficulty with daily activities

name: Sway Back Posture
description: The hips push forward past the line of gravity while the upper body leans back, creating a characteristic 'lazy' S-curve where the person appears to be leaning back while standing.
how_it_forms: Habitual lazy standing posture, leaning back on ligaments
Weak hip flexors and abdominals
Standing for long periods with locked knees
General deconditioning and poor body awareness
Teenage postural habits that persist into adulthood
why_fix: Sway back posture means you're literally hanging on your ligaments instead of using muscles for support. Ligaments are not designed for sustained loading — they creep (slowly stretch) over time, leading to joint instability. The lumbar discs bear load in a shear pattern instead of pure compression, which they're poorly equipped to handle.
biomechanics_explanation: The pelvis shifts anterior to the line of gravity while the thorax shifts posterior. The hip joint reaches end-range extension, and the person hangs on the iliofemoral ligament rather than using muscles. The external obliques and upper abdominals become shortened while the hip flexors become lengthened and weak. The hamstrings shorten to act as a posterior pelvic tilter.
chain_reaction: Sway back → hips pushed forward → knees hyperextend to compensate → posterior pelvic tilt develops → thoracic spine rounds to keep balance → head pushes forward → full postural chain breakdown from bottom to top

severity_indicators.mild: Slight forward hip shift, barely noticeable lazy posture
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible hip forward position, upper body lean back, fatigue with standing
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced sway, chronic lower back pain, ligamentous laxity, difficulty standing straight

name: Knee Valgus (Knock Knees)
description: The knees collapse inward toward the midline, especially under load (squatting, walking stairs, running), creating excessive stress on the medial knee structures.
how_it_forms: Weak gluteus medius failing to control femoral internal rotation
Flat feet/overpronation causing tibial internal rotation
Tight adductors pulling the knee inward
Poor neuromuscular control during dynamic movements
Wide pelvis with insufficient hip strength (common in females)
why_fix: Knee valgus is the number one predictor of ACL tears in athletes. When the knee collapses inward, the ACL is loaded in a way it was never designed to handle — combined valgus and rotation. Even without a traumatic tear, chronic valgus wears the medial meniscus and cartilage unevenly, setting up early-onset knee arthritis. The patella also tracks laterally, grinding into the femoral groove.
biomechanics_explanation: The femur internally rotates and adducts relative to the pelvis due to weak gluteus medius and maximus. The tibia externally rotates relative to the femur. The knee experiences a combined valgus moment with rotation, loading the medial collateral ligament and ACL. The patella is pulled laterally by the altered Q-angle, creating patellofemoral compression.
chain_reaction: Knee valgus → foot overpronates to follow the knee → ankle stability decreases → medial knee overloaded → patella maltracking → anterior knee pain → compensatory movement patterns → hip and lower back stress

severity_indicators.mild: Slight inward knee movement during squats, no pain
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible knee collapse during daily activities, occasional knee pain, difficulty with single-leg balance
severity_indicators.severe: Pronounced valgus at rest, chronic knee pain, history of knee injuries, pain with stairs

name: Genu Recurvatum (Hyperextended Knees)
description: The knees extend past neutral (0 degrees) into hyperextension, with the knee joint pushing backward past the straight-leg position.
how_it_forms: Habitual locking of the knees while standing
Ligamentous laxity (naturally loose joints/hypermobility)
Weak quadriceps failing to control knee extension
Sway back posture pushing knees into extension
Dance or gymnastics training emphasizing straight legs
why_fix: When the knee hyperextends, you're hanging on the posterior capsule and cruciate ligaments instead of using muscle control. These passive structures slowly stretch over time, creating progressive instability. The articular cartilage at the front of the knee gets compressed abnormally, and the posterior blood vessels and nerves can get kinked, reducing circulation to the lower leg.
biomechanics_explanation: The quadriceps and calf muscles create a combined extension moment that pushes the knee past neutral. The hamstrings, which should eccentrically control knee extension, are either weak or have poor timing. The posterior capsule of the knee stretches, allowing progressively more hyperextension. The soleus and gastrocnemius may be tight, contributing to the backward knee position.
chain_reaction: Genu recurvatum → posterior capsule stretches → knee becomes progressively unstable → quadriceps compensate by gripping harder → patellofemoral compression increases → anterior knee pain develops → gait alters to avoid pain → hip and ankle compensations emerge

severity_indicators.mild: Slight hyperextension when standing, knees lock back with inattention
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeable backward knee bend, posterior knee ache, difficulty maintaining soft knees
severity_indicators.severe: Significant hyperextension (>10 degrees), chronic instability, pain, ligamentous laxity

name: Flat Feet / Overpronation
description: The medial arch of the foot collapses, causing the ankle to roll inward (pronate) excessively during standing and walking, which alters the entire lower limb alignment.
how_it_forms: Wearing unsupportive shoes throughout development
Obesity or rapid weight gain overloading the arch
Posterior tibialis tendon weakness or dysfunction
Genetic predisposition to ligamentous laxity
Prolonged standing on hard surfaces without arch support
why_fix: Your foot is the first link in the kinetic chain. When the arch collapses, the tibia internally rotates, the knee follows into valgus, the hip internally rotates, and the pelvis tilts. A 5-degree increase in foot pronation can create a 10-degree change at the knee and 15-degree change at the hip. Every step you take (average 6,000-10,000 per day) reinforces this faulty pattern.
biomechanics_explanation: The posterior tibialis is the primary dynamic arch supporter. When it weakens, the spring ligament and plantar fascia bear the arch load passively. The subtalar joint overpronates, causing the talus to slide medially and the calcaneus to evert. The tibial internal rotation that follows changes the mechanical axis of the entire leg, increasing valgus stress at the knee.
chain_reaction: Flat feet → ankle overpronates → tibia internally rotates → knee collapses into valgus → femur internally rotates → hip drops on opposite side → lateral pelvic tilt → lumbar spine compensates → problems travel up the entire chain

severity_indicators.mild: Slight arch reduction, mild pronation visible during walking, occasional foot fatigue
severity_indicators.moderate: Visible arch collapse when standing, shoes wear unevenly on inside, regular foot/ankle pain
severity_indicators.severe: Complete arch collapse, chronic pain, difficulty with prolonged standing, secondary knee/hip issues

name: Duck Feet (External Tibial Torsion)
description: The feet point outward (externally rotated) during standing and walking, instead of pointing straight ahead, creating inefficient gait mechanics and altered loading patterns.
how_it_forms: Tight external hip rotators (piriformis, deep six)
Weak internal hip rotators and hip flexors
Flat feet causing compensatory foot external rotation
Habitual W-sitting in childhood
Sleeping on stomach with feet turned out
why_fix: When your feet point outward, each step pushes off from the inside of the big toe instead of straight ahead. This medial push-off overloads the plantar fascia, creates a valgus force at the knee, and reduces push-off power by up to 20%. You're essentially walking with your engine misaligned — every step wastes energy and creates abnormal joint loading.
biomechanics_explanation: External tibial torsion and/or femoral retroversion positions the foot in external rotation. The deep external rotators of the hip (piriformis, gemelli, obturators) become shortened. The medial gastrocnemius and tibialis posterior become lengthened. During gait, the foot pushes off in abduction rather than straight-ahead plantarflexion, creating a medial whip pattern that stresses the Achilles and plantar fascia.
chain_reaction: Duck feet → push-off from medial foot → plantar fascia overloaded → ankle rolls inward on each step → tibial external rotation with knee valgus → hip compensates with more external rotation → pattern self-reinforces

severity_indicators.mild: Feet slightly turned out (10-15 degrees), no pain, barely noticeable
severity_indicators.moderate: Noticeable outward foot angle (15-30 degrees), shoe wear pattern visible, occasional pain
severity_indicators.severe: Significant outward rotation (>30 degrees), chronic foot/ankle problems, gait clearly affected
